questions.text: The onset of oogenesis starts during:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Fetal period

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the female gonad , the germ cells undergo a number of rapid mitotic divisions and differentiate into oogonia The number of oogonia reaches its maximum at the 20 th week (about 7 million) Majority of oogonia continue to divide Some oogonia enter into the 1 st meiotic division and are called primary oocytes At birth , no more mitotic division and all oogonia are replaced by primary oocytes. questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum number of oocytes are at birth
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The maximum number of oocytes are at birth

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Max oogonia are at the 20 th week of fetal life (7 million) These reduce (by atresia and apoptosis) to 1-2 million at birth 300-400,000 at puberty 100 at menopause Only 400-500 primary oocytes are likely to ovulate during the reproductive life of a woman The oogonia enter meiosis to form the primary oocyte which rest in the diplotene phase of prophase 1 until puberty Ovulation occurs just after meiosis 1 is complete resulting in a secondary oocyte and the 1 st polar body Meiosis 2 is completed at fertilization resulting in the female pro-nucleus and the 2 nd polar body Oogonia and primary oocytes are diploid Secondary oocytes, ovum and polar bodies are haploid

questions.text: Spermiogenesis includes all the following components except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Sperm capacitation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Spermiogenesis is the process of conversion of spherical spermatids into longitudinal spermatozoa without any change in chromosome number (haploid). It consists of the following: Formation of acrosome Formation of neck, middle piece and tail Nuclear condensation Shedding of most of the cytoplasm Sperm capacitation is the physiological change in which the sperm becomes hyper motile and is able to bind and fertilize a secondary oocyte . This occurs in the fallopian tube.
  • • Spermiogenesis is the process of conversion of spherical spermatids into longitudinal spermatozoa without any change in chromosome number (haploid).

questions.explanation:

questions.text: All are steps in implantation of the zygote except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cleavage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Implantation is the process by which the blastocyst penetrates the uterine mucosa to get implanted in the endometrium It starts on the 6 th day of ovulation (20 th day of LMP) It involves 4 steps Apposition Adhesion Penetration Invasion Cleavage refers to the sub-division of the fertilized ovum into smaller cells
  • • Implantation is the process by which the blastocyst penetrates the uterine mucosa to get implanted in the endometrium

questions.text: A 34y G3P2 presents to the OPD at 34 weeks. She has had 2 previous lower segment cesarean sections and an done at 28 weeks shows an anterior low-lying placenta. She does not complain of bleeding. On examination, the uterus is 32 weeks, cephalic presentation and the FHR is 145 bpm. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Order an ultrasound with a Doppler

questions.correct_answer: A. Order an ultrasound with a Doppler
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa
  • • The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans
  • • Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes
  • • The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated
  • • Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler
  • • Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections. A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections.
  • ➤ A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?

options.label: A
options.text: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer

options.label: B
options.text: Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.correct_answer: D. About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta, The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored. Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
  • • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
  • • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Placenta Accrete Syndromes, the abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1974, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition

questions.text: Match the condition with the time of delivery:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery
  • • Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress
  • • Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred
  • ➤ In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress
  • ➤ In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.
  • ➤ ERef: Page 1982, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ ERef: Page 1982, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A 24y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 28 weeks with painless mild vaginal bleeding. She had a previous similar episode 2 weeks earlier. A scan done was suspicious for placenta accreta and this was confirmed on a Doppler. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Plan an elective LSCS at 37 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Plan an elective classical section at 37 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. Plan an elective classical section at 37 weeks
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ Conservative approaches like leaving the placenta in situ and resection and repair of uterus are less commonly done.
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ

questions.text: Ligation of which of the following vessels in the retroperitoneum will reduce the pulse pressure in a patient who is bleeding during surgery for placenta accreta syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes
  • • It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation

  • • This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Uterine artery ligation is the 1st vessel ligated in devascularization surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation
  • • Option C: External iliac artery: Is not ligated as part of devascularization as it does not supply the uterus
  • • Option D: utero-ovarian anastomoses ligation is done as part of devasculariazation surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is involved in maternal-fetal immune reactions, and may lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn if the mother is Rh-negative and the baby is Rh-positive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. IgG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prevalence of red cell alloimmunization in pregnancy approximates 1% Most cases of severe fetal anemia requiring antenatal transfusion are attributable to anti-D, anti-Kell, anti-c, or anti-E alloimmunization Maternal blood type and antibody screen are routinely assessed at the first prenatal visit. Unbound antibodies in maternal serum are detected with an indirect Coombs test If the result is positive, the specific antibodies are identified; their immunoglobulin subtype is determined as either immunoglobulin G (IgG) or M (IgM); and the titer is quantified. Only IgG antibodies are concerning because IgM antibodies do not cross the placenta

questions.text: How does Immunoglobulin G (IgG) cross the placenta?

options.text: Facilitated diffusion involving calcium binding protein

questions.text: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary source of maternal–fetal transfer. Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi. Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space

questions.text: Which of the following statements about leptin is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is produced exclusively by the placenta

options.label: B
options.text: Concentrations peak in amniotic fluid at term

options.label: C
options.text: 95% of placental production enters the fetal circulation

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormal levels have been associated with FGR

questions.correct_answer: D. Abnormal levels have been associated with FGR
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Leptin is a polypeptide hormone which was originally identified as a product of adipocytes and a regulator of energy homeostasis by curbing appetite. It also contributes to angiogenesis, hemopoiesis, osteogenesis, pulmonary maturation, and neuroendocrine, immune, and reproductive functions Leptin is produced by the mother, fetus, and placenta. It is expressed in syncytiotrophoblasts and fetal vascular endothelial cells. Of placental production, 5% enters the fetal circulation & 95 percent is transferred to the mother. Leptin concentrations peak in amnionic fluid at mid-pregnancy Fetal serum leptin levels begin increasing at approximately 34 weeks and are correlated with fetal weight. This hormone is involved in the development and maturation of the heart, brain, kidneys, and pancreas, and its levels are decreased with fetal-growth restriction. Abnormal levels are also associated with fetal-growth disorders, gestational diabetes, and preeclampsia, but not maternal obesity

  • • Fetal serum leptin levels begin increasing at approximately 34 weeks and are correlated with fetal weight.
  • • This hormone is involved in the development and maturation of the heart, brain, kidneys, and pancreas, and its levels are decreased with fetal-growth restriction.
  • • Abnormal levels are also associated with fetal-growth disorders, gestational diabetes, and preeclampsia, but not maternal obesity

questions.text: Which of the following statements of the fetal thyroid gland is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid

options.label: C
options.text: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life

options.label: D
options.text: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Let us discuss all the options
  • • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks: This is incorrect; the feta thyroid starts secreting hormones at 1- - 12 weeks Option B: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid: Ths is correct. The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid. Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life: This is incorrect. Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth. Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy. This is incorrect. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation
  • • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks: This is incorrect; the feta thyroid starts secreting hormones at 1- - 12 weeks
  • • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks:
  • • Option B: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid: Ths is correct. The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid.
  • • Option B:
  • • By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid: Ths is correct.
  • • Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life: This is incorrect. Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth.
  • • Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life:
  • • Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy. This is incorrect. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation
  • • Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By 10 to 12 weeks, the thyroid gland can synthesize hormones The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation Fetal thyroid hormone plays a role in the normal development of virtually all fetal tissues, especially the brain Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth.

questions.text: Which of the following gives meconium its greenish-black color?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fetal bowel contents consist of various products of secretion, such as glycerophospholipids from the lung, desquamated fetal cells, lanugo, scalp hair, and vernix. It also contains undigested debris from swallowed amnionic fluid. The dark greenish-black color forms from bile pigments, especially biliverdin. Meconium can pass from normal bowel peristalsis in the mature fetus or from vagal stimulation. It can also pass when hypoxia stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) release from the fetal pituitary gland. AVP stimulates colonic smooth muscle to contract, resulting in intra-amnionic defecation Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.

  • • Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.

questions.text: Where does the biosynthesis of surfactant take place?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes. Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film. The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.
  • • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes.
  • • Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film.
  • • The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity
  • • Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.

questions.text: Approximately what percentage of the total hemoglobin is hemoglobin F in a term fetus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Hb is composed of two copies of two different peptide chains, which determine the type of hemoglobin produced Hemoglobin types transition throughout pregnancy. Alpha (α) and zeta (ζ) globin chains are interchangeable. The beta (β) globin chain can be replaced by epsilon (ε), gamma (γ), or delta ( δ) globin chains. In embryonic life (stage I), ζ and ε globin chains exist In fetal life (stage 2): Hemoglobin F is the main type (α and γ globin chains) After birth (stage III), HbA1 predominates (α and β chains)

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 39 weeks' gestation presents with prolonged and severe uterine contractions and reduced variability in the fetal heart rate tracing. The baseline fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most likely cause of this fetal heart rate pattern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fetal distress

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A pattern of prolonged and severe uterine contractions, along with reduced variability in the fetal heart rate tracing, is concerning for fetal distress. Reduced variability can be a sign of fetal compromise, and further evaluation is needed.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 39 weeks' gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. The clinician performs a non-stress test (NST), which shows the absence of accelerations in the fetal heart rate tracing. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Biophysical profile (BPP) assessment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the absence of accelerations on a non-stress test (NST), ideally the NST should be extended till another 20 mins. If there are still no accelerations, a biophysical profile (BPP) assessment is the next best step to evaluate fetal well-being more comprehensively. The BPP includes additional parameters on USG (fetal breathing movements, fetal tone, fetal movements, and amniotic fluid volume) The BPP gives a score (Manning score) and based on this score, further management is advised
  • • In the absence of accelerations on a non-stress test (NST), ideally the NST should be extended till another 20 mins.
  • • If there are still no accelerations, a biophysical profile (BPP) assessment is the next best step to evaluate fetal well-being more comprehensively.
  • • The BPP includes additional parameters on USG (fetal breathing movements, fetal tone, fetal movements, and amniotic fluid volume)
  • • The BPP gives a score (Manning score) and based on this score, further management is advised
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • The decision for delivery (induction of labor/ cesarean) cannot be taken on a non-reactive NST as there is a high false positive rate with an NST Continue routine prenatal care: If the NST is non-reactive, a BPP should be offered and confirmed that the fetus is doing ok.
  • • The decision for delivery (induction of labor/ cesarean) cannot be taken on a non-reactive NST as there is a high false positive rate with an NST
  • • Continue routine prenatal care: If the NST is non-reactive, a BPP should be offered and confirmed that the fetus is doing ok.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ An NST is usually the 1 st test done for antepartum fetal monitoring A non-reactive NST warrants further checking by a Biophysical Profile

questions.text: A pregnant woman with gestational diabetes is scheduled for an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks' gestation. During the procedure, the infant appears lethargic and is not feeding well. What is the most likely cause of the infant's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at risk of hypoglycemia due to the abrupt cessation of the continuous glucose supply from the mother. This is called as Pederson Hypothesis Hypoglycemia can lead to lethargy and respiratory distress in the newborn. Pederson Hypothesis as shown below describes the complications in a neonate of a diabetic mother
